meaning_mnemonic: This radical consists of a single, horizontal stroke. What's the biggest, single, horizontal stroke? That's the <radical>ground</radical>. Look at the ground, look at this radical, now look at the ground again. Kind of the same, right?
These look like <radical>fins</radical>. What's a pair of disembodied fins doing here?! Some fish must have left them here by accident. Bet they're really missing these fins right about now.

This little radical is a <radical>drop</radical>, maybe of water or some other liquid. Notice how it's only one drop? Sometimes radicals and kanji will have more than one drop in them, but don't let that throw you off.

What does this radical look like? Hmm, nothing much. What about if you turn it upside down? Now does it look like a 7 with a line through it? Close enough to help you to remember that this radical is <radical>seven</radical>, right? Just remember, when you see this radical, flip it over and see what number it looks like. If you can do that, you can remember the meaning!

Close your eyes and imagine you're a kid again. Now open them and... look! It's a <radical>slide</radical>! Imagine little you sliding down this slide over and over, having a great time. Imagination + emotion makes for good memorization!

This radical is shaped like a <radical>barb</radical>. Kind of like the barb you'd see on a barbed fishing hook. Imagine that thing getting stuck in your arm or something. Not exactly pleasant. Say out loud, "Oh dang, I got a barb stuck in me!" Alright, relax, it's only a little barb.
One line plus another line equals <radical>two</radical> lines. This radical represents the number two. Pretty simple, right? Can you guess what three looks like? I bet you can...
This looks like something you'd put on a kettle or a pot, right? It even has a little handle to make sure you don't burn yourself. This is some kind of <radical>lid</radical>.

This is a <radical>person</radical>. They're standing with their arms down at their sides and their legs spread out, which kind of makes them look like a torso with a pair of legs. Think of 人 as highlighting the bipedal nature of people. Walking on two legs? Probably a person.

This radical kind of looks like a <radical>toe</radical>. See the one weird toe coming off the side of it? This also looks like the katakana character ト (to), which sounds like the word "toe." So whenever you see ト, just think toe.

If you look at this radical in just the right way, you'll notice that it kind of looks like the letters "n" and "i" (the "i" comes from the little flippy-up stroke on the right side). What do the letters "n" and "i" start spelling? Why, the word <radical>nine</radical>.

Watch out! This isn't the person radical, it's something else. What's the difference? The right side is longer than the left. This radical also has that extra part sticking out at the top. See it? It kind of looks like a person lowering their head to go inside a tent or something. That's why this radical is <radical>enter</radical>.
Imagine a guy flexing his arm downward to show off his steroid-pumped arm. It's huge. It's so full of <radical>power</radical>. RARRRWWWRRR!!

This looks like an enclosure of sorts — that's why it's a <radical>prison</radical>. Imagine a tiny prisoner curled up inside, staring off into space, completely convinced they're trapped forever. Ironically this prison is actually wide open. They're just so consumed with self-pity that they haven't realized they've been free to leave all along.
This radical looks like a <radical>cross</radical>. I mean, just look at it. Two bars going through each other = a cross!
A big, gaping, square hole represents someone opening their giant <radical>mouth</radical> to tell you something stupid.

This radical looks just like a stick figure—more specifically, a really <radical>big</radical> guy with his arms stretched out nice and big. When you see this radical, just think big, because this guy is really BIG!
This radical looks like a woman curtsying. Another way to think of it could be as two stacked Xs, since women generally have XX chromosomes.
This is a <radical>mountain</radical>. See the big peak in the middle and the smaller ones on either side? This totally looks like a mountain.

This radical already looks like a <radical>river</radical>. See how the lines represent the flow of the river? There's even a slight bend in this river. So when you see this radical, you should think "river."

Since there are no circles in Japanese characters, sometimes rectangles or squares have to make do. In this case, this big rectangle is the <radical>sun</radical>. The middle line is a cloud, moving across the sun. Picture it, but don't actually look at the sun and burn your eyes!
Do you see the <radical>tree</radical> in here? It has branches, and then it has the foliage coming down diagonally from it, spreading out like a tree would. That's why this radical is a tree.

You know those big steel girders that are used for the frame of big buildings? This is like the end of one of those, and has a very distinct shape, just like this radical. These girders are used in construction, which is why this radical means <radical>construction</radical>. Funny thing is, you use these girders to put together buildings just like you're going to use this radical to put together kanji!
This is a <radical>stick</radical>, sticking straight up. It even looks like a stick.
This looks a lot like a <radical>gun</radical> pointing to the right. You have a handle on the left, and the barrel pointing to the right. Imagine it hanging in a case on the wall in a museum.
